20 /*
21  * Following is Doug Lea's memory allocator with USE_MALLOC_INSTEAD
22  * feature amendment
23  *
24  * USE_MALLOC_INSTEAD
25  * When this feature is enabled, uses system malloc/free instead of mmap/munmap.
26  *
27  * ENABLE_SEPARATE_MMAP_EVENT_TRACE
28  * Fix the problem that mmaped (malloced when USE_MALLOC_INSTEAD is 1)
29  * memory region (which is returned by mmap_alloc function) is not
30  * automatically freed when destroy_mspace is called.
31  *
32  */
33 
34 /*===========================================================================*/
35 /*===========================================================================*/
36 /*===========================================================================*/
37 
38 /*
39  This is a version (aka dlmalloc) of malloc/free/realloc written by
40  Doug Lea and released to the public domain, as explained at
41  http://creativecommons.org/licenses/publicdomain. Send questions,
42  comments, complaints, performance data, etc to dl@cs.oswego.edu
43 
44 * Version 2.8.3 Thu Sep 22 11:16:15 2005 Doug Lea (dl at gee)
45 
46  Note: There may be an updated version of this malloc obtainable at
47  ftp://gee.cs.oswego.edu/pub/misc/malloc.c
48  Check before installing!
49 
50 * Quickstart
51 
52  This library is all in one file to simplify the most common usage:
53  ftp it, compile it (-O3), and link it into another program. All of
54  the compile-time options default to reasonable values for use on
55  most platforms. You might later want to step through various
56  compile-time and dynamic tuning options.
57 
58  For convenience, an include file for code using this malloc is at:
59  ftp://gee.cs.oswego.edu/pub/misc/malloc-2.8.3.h
60  You don't really need this .h file unless you call functions not
61  defined in your system include files. The .h file contains only the
62  excerpts from this file needed for using this malloc on ANSI C/C++
63  systems, so long as you haven't changed compile-time options about
64  naming and tuning parameters. If you do, then you can create your
65  own malloc.h that does include all settings by cutting at the point
66  indicated below. Note that you may already by default be using a C
67  library containing a malloc that is based on some version of this
68  malloc (for example in linux). You might still want to use the one
69  in this file to customize settings or to avoid overheads associated
70  with library versions.
71 
72 * Vital statistics:
73 
74  Supported pointer/size_t representation: 4 or 8 bytes
75  size_t MUST be an unsigned type of the same width as
76  pointers. (If you are using an ancient system that declares
77  size_t as a signed type, or need it to be a different width
78  than pointers, you can use a previous release of this malloc
79  (e.g. 2.7.2) supporting these.)
80 
81  Alignment: 8 bytes (default)
82  This suffices for nearly all current machines and C compilers.
83  However, you can define MALLOC_ALIGNMENT to be wider than this
84  if necessary (up to 128bytes), at the expense of using more space.
85 
86  Minimum overhead per allocated chunk: 4 or 8 bytes (if 4byte sizes)
87  8 or 16 bytes (if 8byte sizes)
88  Each malloced chunk has a hidden word of overhead holding size
89  and status information, and additional cross-check word
90  if FOOTERS is defined.
91 
92  Minimum allocated size: 4-byte ptrs: 16 bytes (including overhead)
93  8-byte ptrs: 32 bytes (including overhead)
94 
95  Even a request for zero bytes (i.e., malloc(0)) returns a
96  pointer to something of the minimum allocatable size.
97  The maximum overhead wastage (i.e., number of extra bytes
98  allocated than were requested in malloc) is less than or equal
99  to the minimum size, except for requests >= mmap_threshold that
100  are serviced via mmap(), where the worst case wastage is about
101  32 bytes plus the remainder from a system page (the minimal
102  mmap unit); typically 4096 or 8192 bytes.
103 
104  Security: static-safe; optionally more or less
105  The "security" of malloc refers to the ability of malicious
106  code to accentuate the effects of errors (for example, freeing
107  space that is not currently malloc'ed or overwriting past the
108  ends of chunks) in code that calls malloc. This malloc
109  guarantees not to modify any memory locations below the base of
110  heap, i.e., static variables, even in the presence of usage
111  errors. The routines additionally detect most improper frees
112  and reallocs. All this holds as long as the static bookkeeping
113  for malloc itself is not corrupted by some other means. This
114  is only one aspect of security -- these checks do not, and
115  cannot, detect all possible programming errors.
116 
117  If FOOTERS is defined nonzero, then each allocated chunk
118  carries an additional check word to verify that it was malloced
119  from its space. These check words are the same within each
120  execution of a program using malloc, but differ across
121  executions, so externally crafted fake chunks cannot be
122  freed. This improves security by rejecting frees/reallocs that
123  could corrupt heap memory, in addition to the checks preventing
124  writes to statics that are always on. This may further improve
125  security at the expense of time and space overhead. (Note that
126  FOOTERS may also be worth using with MSPACES.)
127 
128  By default detected errors cause the program to abort (calling
129  "abort()"). You can override this to instead proceed past
130  errors by defining PROCEED_ON_ERROR. In this case, a bad free
131  has no effect, and a malloc that encounters a bad address
132  caused by user overwrites will ignore the bad address by
133  dropping pointers and indices to all known memory. This may
134  be appropriate for programs that should continue if at all
135  possible in the face of programming errors, although they may
136  run out of memory because dropped memory is never reclaimed.
137 
138  If you don't like either of these options, you can define
139  CORRUPTION_ERROR_ACTION and USAGE_ERROR_ACTION to do anything
140  else. And if if you are sure that your program using malloc has
141  no errors or vulnerabilities, you can define INSECURE to 1,
142  which might (or might not) provide a small performance improvement.
143 
144  Thread-safety: NOT thread-safe unless USE_LOCKS defined
145  When USE_LOCKS is defined, each public call to malloc, free,
146  etc is surrounded with either a pthread mutex or a win32
147  spinlock (depending on WIN32). This is not especially fast, and
148  can be a major bottleneck. It is designed only to provide
149  minimal protection in concurrent environments, and to provide a
150  basis for extensions. If you are using malloc in a concurrent
151  program, consider instead using ptmalloc, which is derived from
152  a version of this malloc. (See http://www.malloc.de).
153 
154  System requirements: Any combination of MORECORE and/or MMAP/MUNMAP
155  This malloc can use unix sbrk or any emulation (invoked using
156  the CALL_MORECORE macro) and/or mmap/munmap or any emulation
157  (invoked using CALL_MMAP/CALL_MUNMAP) to get and release system
158  memory. On most unix systems, it tends to work best if both
159  MORECORE and MMAP are enabled. On Win32, it uses emulations
160  based on VirtualAlloc. It also uses common C library functions
161  like memset.
162 
163  Compliance: I believe it is compliant with the Single Unix Specification
164  (See http://www.unix.org). Also SVID/XPG, ANSI C, and probably
165  others as well.
166 
167 * Overview of algorithms
168 
169  This is not the fastest, most space-conserving, most portable, or
170  most tunable malloc ever written. However it is among the fastest
171  while also being among the most space-conserving, portable and
172  tunable. Consistent balance across these factors results in a good
173  general-purpose allocator for malloc-intensive programs.
174 
175  In most ways, this malloc is a best-fit allocator. Generally, it
176  chooses the best-fitting existing chunk for a request, with ties
177  broken in approximately least-recently-used order. (This strategy
178  normally maintains low fragmentation.) However, for requests less
179  than 256bytes, it deviates from best-fit when there is not an
180  exactly fitting available chunk by preferring to use space adjacent
181  to that used for the previous small request, as well as by breaking
182  ties in approximately most-recently-used order. (These enhance
183  locality of series of small allocations.) And for very large requests
184  (>= 256Kb by default), it relies on system memory mapping
185  facilities, if supported. (This helps avoid carrying around and
186  possibly fragmenting memory used only for large chunks.)
187 
188  All operations (except malloc_stats and mallinfo) have execution
189  times that are bounded by a constant factor of the number of bits in
190  a size_t, not counting any clearing in calloc or copying in realloc,
191  or actions surrounding MORECORE and MMAP that have times
192  proportional to the number of non-contiguous regions returned by
193  system allocation routines, which is often just 1.
194 
195  The implementation is not very modular and seriously overuses
196  macros. Perhaps someday all C compilers will do as good a job
197  inlining modular code as can now be done by brute-force expansion,
198  but now, enough of them seem not to.
199 
200  Some compilers issue a lot of warnings about code that is
201  dead/unreachable only on some platforms, and also about intentional
202  uses of negation on unsigned types. All known cases of each can be
203  ignored.
204 
205  For a longer but out of date high-level description, see
206  http://gee.cs.oswego.edu/dl/html/malloc.html
207 
208 * MSPACES
209  If MSPACES is defined, then in addition to malloc, free, etc.,
210  this file also defines mspace_malloc, mspace_free, etc. These
211  are versions of malloc routines that take an "mspace" argument
212  obtained using create_mspace, to control all internal bookkeeping.
213  If ONLY_MSPACES is defined, only these versions are compiled.
214  So if you would like to use this allocator for only some allocations,
215  and your system malloc for others, you can compile with
216  ONLY_MSPACES and then do something like...
217  static mspace mymspace = create_mspace(0,0); // for example
218  #define mymalloc(bytes) mspace_malloc(mymspace, bytes)
219 
220  (Note: If you only need one instance of an mspace, you can instead
221  use "USE_DL_PREFIX" to relabel the global malloc.)
222 
223  You can similarly create thread-local allocators by storing
224  mspaces as thread-locals. For example:
225  static __thread mspace tlms = 0;
226  void* tlmalloc(size_t bytes) {
227  if (tlms == 0) tlms = create_mspace(0, 0);
228  return mspace_malloc(tlms, bytes);
229  }
230  void tlfree(void* mem) { mspace_free(tlms, mem); }
231 
232  Unless FOOTERS is defined, each mspace is completely independent.
233  You cannot allocate from one and free to another (although
234  conformance is only weakly checked, so usage errors are not always
235  caught). If FOOTERS is defined, then each chunk carries around a tag
236  indicating its originating mspace, and frees are directed to their
237  originating spaces.
238 
239  ------------------------- Compile-time options ---------------------------
240 
241 Be careful in setting #define values for numerical constants of type
242 size_t. On some systems, literal values are not automatically extended
243 to size_t precision unless they are explicitly casted.
244 
245 WIN32 default: defined if _WIN32 defined
246  Defining WIN32 sets up defaults for MS environment and compilers.
247  Otherwise defaults are for unix.
248 
249 MALLOC_ALIGNMENT default: (size_t)8
250  Controls the minimum alignment for malloc'ed chunks. It must be a
251  power of two and at least 8, even on machines for which smaller
252  alignments would suffice. It may be defined as larger than this
253  though. Note however that code and data structures are optimized for
254  the case of 8-byte alignment.
255 
256 MSPACES default: 0 (false)
257  If true, compile in support for independent allocation spaces.
258  This is only supported if HAVE_MMAP is true.
259 
260 ONLY_MSPACES default: 0 (false)
261  If true, only compile in mspace versions, not regular versions.
262 
263 USE_LOCKS default: 0 (false)
264  Causes each call to each public routine to be surrounded with
265  pthread or WIN32 mutex lock/unlock. (If set true, this can be
266  overridden on a per-mspace basis for mspace versions.)
267 
268 FOOTERS default: 0
269  If true, provide extra checking and dispatching by placing
270  information in the footers of allocated chunks. This adds
271  space and time overhead.
272 
273 INSECURE default: 0
274  If true, omit checks for usage errors and heap space overwrites.
275 
276 USE_DL_PREFIX default: NOT defined
277  Causes compiler to prefix all public routines with the string 'dl'.
278  This can be useful when you only want to use this malloc in one part
279  of a program, using your regular system malloc elsewhere.
280 
281 ABORT default: defined as abort()
282  Defines how to abort on failed checks. On most systems, a failed
283  check cannot die with an "assert" or even print an informative
284  message, because the underlying print routines in turn call malloc,
285  which will fail again. Generally, the best policy is to simply call
286  abort(). It's not very useful to do more than this because many
287  errors due to overwriting will show up as address faults (null, odd
288  addresses etc) rather than malloc-triggered checks, so will also
289  abort. Also, most compilers know that abort() does not return, so
290  can better optimize code conditionally calling it.
291 
292 PROCEED_ON_ERROR default: defined as 0 (false)
293  Controls whether detected bad addresses cause them to bypassed
294  rather than aborting. If set, detected bad arguments to free and
295  realloc are ignored. And all bookkeeping information is zeroed out
296  upon a detected overwrite of freed heap space, thus losing the
297  ability to ever return it from malloc again, but enabling the
298  application to proceed. If PROCEED_ON_ERROR is defined, the
299  static variable malloc_corruption_error_count is compiled in
300  and can be examined to see if errors have occurred. This option
301  generates slower code than the default abort policy.
302 
303 DEBUG default: NOT defined
304  The DEBUG setting is mainly intended for people trying to modify
305  this code or diagnose problems when porting to new platforms.
306  However, it may also be able to better isolate user errors than just
307  using runtime checks. The assertions in the check routines spell
308  out in more detail the assumptions and invariants underlying the
309  algorithms. The checking is fairly extensive, and will slow down
310  execution noticeably. Calling malloc_stats or mallinfo with DEBUG
311  set will attempt to check every non-mmapped allocated and free chunk
312  in the course of computing the summaries.
313 
314 ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE default: defined as 1 (true)
315  Debugging assertion failures can be nearly impossible if your
316  version of the assert macro causes malloc to be called, which will
317  lead to a cascade of further failures, blowing the runtime stack.
318  ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE cause assertions failures to call abort(),
319  which will usually make debugging easier.
320 
321 MALLOC_FAILURE_ACTION default: sets errno to ENOMEM, or no-op on win32
322  The action to take before "return 0" when malloc fails to be able to
323  return memory because there is none available.
324 
325 HAVE_MORECORE default: 1 (true) unless win32 or ONLY_MSPACES
326  True if this system supports sbrk or an emulation of it.
327 
328 MORECORE default: sbrk
329  The name of the sbrk-style system routine to call to obtain more
330  memory. See below for guidance on writing custom MORECORE
331  functions. The type of the argument to sbrk/MORECORE varies across
332  systems. It cannot be size_t, because it supports negative
333  arguments, so it is normally the signed type of the same width as
334  size_t (sometimes declared as "intptr_t"). It doesn't much matter
335  though. Internally, we only call it with arguments less than half
336  the max value of a size_t, which should work across all reasonable
337  possibilities, although sometimes generating compiler warnings. See
338  near the end of this file for guidelines for creating a custom
339  version of MORECORE.
340 
341 MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS default: 1 (true)
342  If true, take advantage of fact that consecutive calls to MORECORE
343  with positive arguments always return contiguous increasing
344  addresses. This is true of unix sbrk. It does not hurt too much to
345  set it true anyway, since malloc copes with non-contiguities.
346  Setting it false when definitely non-contiguous saves time
347  and possibly wasted space it would take to discover this though.
348 
349 MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM default: NOT defined
350  True if MORECORE cannot release space back to the system when given
351  negative arguments. This is generally necessary only if you are
352  using a hand-crafted MORECORE function that cannot handle negative
353  arguments.
354 
355 HAVE_MMAP default: 1 (true)
356  True if this system supports mmap or an emulation of it. If so, and
357  HAVE_MORECORE is not true, MMAP is used for all system
358  allocation. If set and HAVE_MORECORE is true as well, MMAP is
359  primarily used to directly allocate very large blocks. It is also
360  used as a backup strategy in cases where MORECORE fails to provide
361  space from system. Note: A single call to MUNMAP is assumed to be
362  able to unmap memory that may have be allocated using multiple calls
363  to MMAP, so long as they are adjacent.
364 
365 HAVE_MREMAP default: 1 on linux, else 0
366  If true realloc() uses mremap() to re-allocate large blocks and
367  extend or shrink allocation spaces.
368 
369 MMAP_CLEARS default: 1 on unix
370  True if mmap clears memory so calloc doesn't need to. This is true
371  for standard unix mmap using /dev/zero.
372 
373 USE_BUILTIN_FFS default: 0 (i.e., not used)
374  Causes malloc to use the builtin ffs() function to compute indices.
375  Some compilers may recognize and intrinsify ffs to be faster than the
376  supplied C version. Also, the case of x86 using gcc is special-cased
377  to an asm instruction, so is already as fast as it can be, and so
378  this setting has no effect. (On most x86s, the asm version is only
379  slightly faster than the C version.)
380 
381 malloc_getpagesize default: derive from system includes, or 4096.
382  The system page size. To the extent possible, this malloc manages
383  memory from the system in page-size units. This may be (and
384  usually is) a function rather than a constant. This is ignored
385  if WIN32, where page size is determined using getSystemInfo during
386  initialization.
387 
388 USE_DEV_RANDOM default: 0 (i.e., not used)
389  Causes malloc to use /dev/random to initialize secure magic seed for
390  stamping footers. Otherwise, the current time is used.
391 
392 NO_MALLINFO default: 0
393  If defined, don't compile "mallinfo". This can be a simple way
394  of dealing with mismatches between system declarations and
395  those in this file.
396 
397 MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE default: size_t
398  The type of the fields in the mallinfo struct. This was originally
399  defined as "int" in SVID etc, but is more usefully defined as
400  size_t. The value is used only if HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H is not set
401 
402 REALLOC_ZERO_BYTES_FREES default: not defined
403  This should be set if a call to realloc with zero bytes should
404  be the same as a call to free. Some people think it should. Otherwise,
405  since this malloc returns a unique pointer for malloc(0), so does
406  realloc(p, 0).
407 
408 LACKS_UNISTD_H, LACKS_FCNTL_H, LACKS_SYS_PARAM_H, LACKS_SYS_MMAN_H
409 LACKS_STRINGS_H, LACKS_STRING_H, LACKS_SYS_TYPES_H, LACKS_ERRNO_H
410 LACKS_STDLIB_H default: NOT defined unless on WIN32
411  Define these if your system does not have these header files.
412  You might need to manually insert some of the declarations they provide.
413 
414 DEFAULT_GRANULARITY default: page size if MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS,
415  system_info.dwAllocationGranularity in WIN32,
416  otherwise 64K.
417  Also settable using mallopt(M_GRANULARITY, x)
418  The unit for allocating and deallocating memory from the system. On
419  most systems with contiguous MORECORE, there is no reason to
420  make this more than a page. However, systems with MMAP tend to
421  either require or encourage larger granularities. You can increase
422  this value to prevent system allocation functions to be called so
423  often, especially if they are slow. The value must be at least one
424  page and must be a power of two. Setting to 0 causes initialization
425  to either page size or win32 region size. (Note: In previous
426  versions of malloc, the equivalent of this option was called
427  "TOP_PAD")
428 
429 DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD default: 2MB
430  Also settable using mallopt(M_TRIM_THRESHOLD, x)
431  The maximum amount of unused top-most memory to keep before
432  releasing via malloc_trim in free(). Automatic trimming is mainly
433  useful in long-lived programs using contiguous MORECORE. Because
434  trimming via sbrk can be slow on some systems, and can sometimes be
435  wasteful (in cases where programs immediately afterward allocate
436  more large chunks) the value should be high enough so that your
437  overall system performance would improve by releasing this much
438  memory. As a rough guide, you might set to a value close to the
439  average size of a process (program) running on your system.
440  Releasing this much memory would allow such a process to run in
441  memory. Generally, it is worth tuning trim thresholds when a
442  program undergoes phases where several large chunks are allocated
443  and released in ways that can reuse each other's storage, perhaps
444  mixed with phases where there are no such chunks at all. The trim
445  value must be greater than page size to have any useful effect. To
446  disable trimming completely, you can set to MAX_SIZE_T. Note that the trick
447  some people use of mallocing a huge space and then freeing it at
448  program startup, in an attempt to reserve system memory, doesn't
449  have the intended effect under automatic trimming, since that memory
450  will immediately be returned to the system.
451 
452 DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD default: 256K
453  Also settable using mallopt(M_MMAP_THRESHOLD, x)
454  The request size threshold for using MMAP to directly service a
455  request. Requests of at least this size that cannot be allocated
456  using already-existing space will be serviced via mmap. (If enough
457  normal freed space already exists it is used instead.) Using mmap
458  segregates relatively large chunks of memory so that they can be
459  individually obtained and released from the host system. A request
460  serviced through mmap is never reused by any other request (at least
461  not directly; the system may just so happen to remap successive
462  requests to the same locations). Segregating space in this way has
463  the benefits that: Mmapped space can always be individually released
464  back to the system, which helps keep the system level memory demands
465  of a long-lived program low. Also, mapped memory doesn't become
466  `locked' between other chunks, as can happen with normally allocated
467  chunks, which means that even trimming via malloc_trim would not
468  release them. However, it has the disadvantage that the space
469  cannot be reclaimed, consolidated, and then used to service later
470  requests, as happens with normal chunks. The advantages of mmap
471  nearly always outweigh disadvantages for "large" chunks, but the
472  value of "large" may vary across systems. The default is an
473  empirically derived value that works well in most systems. You can
474  disable mmap by setting to MAX_SIZE_T.
475 
476 */
477

512 #define MAX_SIZE_T (~(size_t)0)

517 #ifndef MSPACES

522 #endif /* ONLY_MSPACES */
523 #endif /* MSPACES */

526 #endif /* MALLOC_ALIGNMENT */

529 #endif /* FOOTERS */
530 #ifndef ABORT
531 #define ABORT abort()
532 #endif /* ABORT */
533 #ifndef ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE
534 #define ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE 1
535 #endif /* ABORT_ON_ASSERT_FAILURE */
536 #ifndef PROCEED_ON_ERROR
537 #define PROCEED_ON_ERROR 0
538 #endif /* PROCEED_ON_ERROR */
539 #ifndef USE_LOCKS
540 #define USE_LOCKS 0
541 #endif /* USE_LOCKS */
542 #ifndef INSECURE
543 #define INSECURE 0
544 #endif /* INSECURE */
545 #ifndef HAVE_MMAP
546 #define HAVE_MMAP 1
547 #endif /* HAVE_MMAP */
548 #ifndef MMAP_CLEARS
549 #define MMAP_CLEARS 1
550 #endif /* MMAP_CLEARS */
551 #ifndef HAVE_MREMAP
552 #ifdef linux
553 #define HAVE_MREMAP 1
554 #else /* linux */
555 #define HAVE_MREMAP 0
556 #endif /* linux */
557 #endif /* HAVE_MREMAP */
558 #ifndef MALLOC_FAILURE_ACTION
559 #define MALLOC_FAILURE_ACTION errno = ENOMEM;
560 #endif /* MALLOC_FAILURE_ACTION */
561 #ifndef HAVE_MORECORE
562 #if ONLY_MSPACES

573 #endif /* MORECORE */

576 #endif /* MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS */
577 #endif /* HAVE_MORECORE */

581 #else /* MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS */
582 #define DEFAULT_GRANULARITY ((size_t)64U * (size_t)1024U)
583 #endif /* MORECORE_CONTIGUOUS */
584 #endif /* DEFAULT_GRANULARITY */
585 #ifndef DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD
586 #ifndef MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM
587 #define DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD ((size_t)2U * (size_t)1024U * (size_t)1024U)
588 #else /* MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM */
589 #define DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD MAX_SIZE_T
590 #endif /* MORECORE_CANNOT_TRIM */
591 #endif /* DEFAULT_TRIM_THRESHOLD */
592 #ifndef DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD
593 #if HAVE_MMAP
594 #define DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD ((size_t)256U * (size_t)1024U)
595 #else /* HAVE_MMAP */
596 #define DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD MAX_SIZE_T
597 #endif /* HAVE_MMAP */
598 #endif /* DEFAULT_MMAP_THRESHOLD */
599 #ifndef USE_BUILTIN_FFS
600 #define USE_BUILTIN_FFS 0
601 #endif /* USE_BUILTIN_FFS */

603 #define USE_DEV_RANDOM 0
604 #endif /* USE_DEV_RANDOM */
605 #ifndef NO_MALLINFO
606 #define NO_MALLINFO 0
607 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
608 #ifndef MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE

610 #endif /* MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE */

612 /*
613  mallopt tuning options. SVID/XPG defines four standard parameter
614  numbers for mallopt, normally defined in malloc.h. None of these
615  are used in this malloc, so setting them has no effect. But this
616  malloc does support the following options.
617 */
618 
619 #define M_TRIM_THRESHOLD (-1)
620 #define M_GRANULARITY (-2)
621 #define M_MMAP_THRESHOLD (-3)
622 
623 /* ------------------------ Mallinfo declarations ------------------------ */
624 
625 #if !NO_MALLINFO
626 /*
627  This version of malloc supports the standard SVID/XPG mallinfo
628  routine that returns a struct containing usage properties and
629  statistics. It should work on any system that has a
630  /usr/include/malloc.h defining struct mallinfo. The main
631  declaration needed is the mallinfo struct that is returned (by-copy)
632  by mallinfo(). The malloinfo struct contains a bunch of fields that
633  are not even meaningful in this version of malloc. These fields are
634  are instead filled by mallinfo() with other numbers that might be of
635  interest.
636 
637  HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H should be set if you have a
638  /usr/include/malloc.h file that includes a declaration of struct
639  mallinfo. If so, it is included; else a compliant version is
640  declared below. These must be precisely the same for mallinfo() to
641  work. The original SVID version of this struct, defined on most
642  systems with mallinfo, declares all fields as ints. But some others
643  define as unsigned long. If your system defines the fields using a
644  type of different width than listed here, you MUST #include your
645  system version and #define HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H.
646 */
647 
648 /* #define HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
649 
650 #ifdef HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H
651 #include "/usr/include/malloc.h"
652 #else /* HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
653 
654 struct mallinfo
655 {
656  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE arena; /* non-mmapped space allocated from system */
657  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE ordblks; /* number of free chunks */
658  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE smblks; /* always 0 */
659  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE hblks; /* always 0 */
660  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE hblkhd; /* space in mmapped regions */
661  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE usmblks; /* maximum total allocated space */
662  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE fsmblks; /* always 0 */
663  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE uordblks; /* total allocated space */
664  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE fordblks; /* total free space */
665  MALLINFO_FIELD_TYPE keepcost; /* releasable (via malloc_trim) space */
666 };
667 
668 #endif /* HAVE_USR_INCLUDE_MALLOC_H */
669 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
670 
671 #ifdef __cplusplus
672 extern "C"
673 {
674 #endif /* __cplusplus */
675 
676 #if !ONLY_MSPACES
677 
678 /* ------------------- Declarations of public routines ------------------- */
679 
680 #ifndef USE_DL_PREFIX
681 #define dlcalloc calloc
682 #define dlfree free
683 #define dlmalloc malloc
684 #define dlmemalign memalign
685 #define dlrealloc realloc
686 #define dlvalloc valloc
687 #define dlpvalloc pvalloc
688 #define dlmallinfo mallinfo
689 #define dlmallopt mallopt
690 #define dlmalloc_trim malloc_trim
691 #define dlmalloc_stats malloc_stats
692 #define dlmalloc_usable_size malloc_usable_size
693 #define dlmalloc_footprint malloc_footprint
694 #define dlmalloc_max_footprint malloc_max_footprint
695 #define dlindependent_calloc independent_calloc
696 #define dlindependent_comalloc independent_comalloc
697 #endif /* USE_DL_PREFIX */

699 
700 /*
701  malloc(size_t n)
702  Returns a pointer to a newly allocated chunk of at least n bytes, or
703  null if no space is available, in which case errno is set to ENOMEM
704  on ANSI C systems.
705 
706  If n is zero, malloc returns a minimum-sized chunk. (The minimum
707  size is 16 bytes on most 32bit systems, and 32 bytes on 64bit
708  systems.) Note that size_t is an unsigned type, so calls with
709  arguments that would be negative if signed are interpreted as
710  requests for huge amounts of space, which will often fail. The
711  maximum supported value of n differs across systems, but is in all
712  cases less than the maximum representable value of a size_t.
713 */
714  void *dlmalloc (size_t);
715 
716 /*
717  free(void* p)
718  Releases the chunk of memory pointed to by p, that had been previously
719  allocated using malloc or a related routine such as realloc.
720  It has no effect if p is null. If p was not malloced or already
721  freed, free(p) will by default cause the current program to abort.
722 */
723  void dlfree (void *);
724 
725 /*
726  calloc(size_t n_elements, size_t element_size);
727  Returns a pointer to n_elements * element_size bytes, with all locations
728  set to zero.
729 */
730  void *dlcalloc (size_t, size_t);
731 
732 /*
733  realloc(void* p, size_t n)
734  Returns a pointer to a chunk of size n that contains the same data
735  as does chunk p up to the minimum of (n, p's size) bytes, or null
736  if no space is available.
737 
738  The returned pointer may or may not be the same as p. The algorithm
739  prefers extending p in most cases when possible, otherwise it
740  employs the equivalent of a malloc-copy-free sequence.
741 
742  If p is null, realloc is equivalent to malloc.
743 
744  If space is not available, realloc returns null, errno is set (if on
745  ANSI) and p is NOT freed.
746 
747  if n is for fewer bytes than already held by p, the newly unused
748  space is lopped off and freed if possible. realloc with a size
749  argument of zero (re)allocates a minimum-sized chunk.
750 
751  The old unix realloc convention of allowing the last-free'd chunk
752  to be used as an argument to realloc is not supported.
753 */
754 
755  void *dlrealloc (void *, size_t);
756 
757 /*
758  memalign(size_t alignment, size_t n);
759  Returns a pointer to a newly allocated chunk of n bytes, aligned
760  in accord with the alignment argument.
761 
762  The alignment argument should be a power of two. If the argument is
763  not a power of two, the nearest greater power is used.
764  8-byte alignment is guaranteed by normal malloc calls, so don't
765  bother calling memalign with an argument of 8 or less.
766 
767  Overreliance on memalign is a sure way to fragment space.
768 */
769  void *dlmemalign (size_t, size_t);
770 
771 /*
772  valloc(size_t n);
773  Equivalent to memalign(pagesize, n), where pagesize is the page
774  size of the system. If the pagesize is unknown, 4096 is used.
775 */
776  void *dlvalloc (size_t);
777 
778 /*
779  mallopt(int parameter_number, int parameter_value)
780  Sets tunable parameters The format is to provide a
781  (parameter-number, parameter-value) pair. mallopt then sets the
782  corresponding parameter to the argument value if it can (i.e., so
783  long as the value is meaningful), and returns 1 if successful else
784  0. SVID/XPG/ANSI defines four standard param numbers for mallopt,
785  normally defined in malloc.h. None of these are use in this malloc,
786  so setting them has no effect. But this malloc also supports other
787  options in mallopt. See below for details. Briefly, supported
788  parameters are as follows (listed defaults are for "typical"
789  configurations).
790 
791  Symbol param # default allowed param values
792  M_TRIM_THRESHOLD -1 2*1024*1024 any (MAX_SIZE_T disables)
793  M_GRANULARITY -2 page size any power of 2 >= page size
794  M_MMAP_THRESHOLD -3 256*1024 any (or 0 if no MMAP support)
795 */
796  int dlmallopt (int, int);
797 
798 /*
799  malloc_footprint();
800  Returns the number of bytes obtained from the system. The total
801  number of bytes allocated by malloc, realloc etc., is less than this
802  value. Unlike mallinfo, this function returns only a precomputed
803  result, so can be called frequently to monitor memory consumption.
804  Even if locks are otherwise defined, this function does not use them,
805  so results might not be up to date.
806 */
807  size_t dlmalloc_footprint (void);
808 
809 /*
810  malloc_max_footprint();
811  Returns the maximum number of bytes obtained from the system. This
812  value will be greater than current footprint if deallocated space
813  has been reclaimed by the system. The peak number of bytes allocated
814  by malloc, realloc etc., is less than this value. Unlike mallinfo,
815  this function returns only a precomputed result, so can be called
816  frequently to monitor memory consumption. Even if locks are
817  otherwise defined, this function does not use them, so results might
818  not be up to date.
819 */
820  size_t dlmalloc_max_footprint (void);
821 
822 #if !NO_MALLINFO
823 /*
824  mallinfo()
825  Returns (by copy) a struct containing various summary statistics:
826 
827  arena: current total non-mmapped bytes allocated from system
828  ordblks: the number of free chunks
829  smblks: always zero.
830  hblks: current number of mmapped regions
831  hblkhd: total bytes held in mmapped regions
832  usmblks: the maximum total allocated space. This will be greater
833  than current total if trimming has occurred.
834  fsmblks: always zero
835  uordblks: current total allocated space (normal or mmapped)
836  fordblks: total free space
837  keepcost: the maximum number of bytes that could ideally be released
838  back to system via malloc_trim. ("ideally" means that
839  it ignores page restrictions etc.)
840 
841  Because these fields are ints, but internal bookkeeping may
842  be kept as longs, the reported values may wrap around zero and
843  thus be inaccurate.
844 */
845  struct mallinfo dlmallinfo (void);
846 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
847 
848 /*
849  independent_calloc(size_t n_elements, size_t element_size, void* chunks[]);
850 
851  independent_calloc is similar to calloc, but instead of returning a
852  single cleared space, it returns an array of pointers to n_elements
853  independent elements that can hold contents of size elem_size, each
854  of which starts out cleared, and can be independently freed,
855  realloc'ed etc. The elements are guaranteed to be adjacently
856  allocated (this is not guaranteed to occur with multiple callocs or
857  mallocs), which may also improve cache locality in some
858  applications.
859 
860  The "chunks" argument is optional (i.e., may be null, which is
861  probably the most typical usage). If it is null, the returned array
862  is itself dynamically allocated and should also be freed when it is
863  no longer needed. Otherwise, the chunks array must be of at least
864  n_elements in length. It is filled in with the pointers to the
865  chunks.
866 
867  In either case, independent_calloc returns this pointer array, or
868  null if the allocation failed. If n_elements is zero and "chunks"
869  is null, it returns a chunk representing an array with zero elements
870  (which should be freed if not wanted).
871 
872  Each element must be individually freed when it is no longer
873  needed. If you'd like to instead be able to free all at once, you
874  should instead use regular calloc and assign pointers into this
875  space to represent elements. (In this case though, you cannot
876  independently free elements.)
877 
878  independent_calloc simplifies and speeds up implementations of many
879  kinds of pools. It may also be useful when constructing large data
880  structures that initially have a fixed number of fixed-sized nodes,
881  but the number is not known at compile time, and some of the nodes
882  may later need to be freed. For example:
883 
884  struct Node { int item; struct Node* next; };
885 
886  struct Node* build_list() {
887  struct Node** pool;
888  int n = read_number_of_nodes_needed();
889  if (n <= 0) return 0;
890  pool = (struct Node**)(independent_calloc(n, sizeof(struct Node), 0);
891  if (pool == 0) die();
892  // organize into a linked list...
893  struct Node* first = pool[0];
894  for (i = 0; i < n-1; ++i)
895  pool[i]->next = pool[i+1];
896  free(pool); // Can now free the array (or not, if it is needed later)
897  return first;
898  }
899 */
900  void **dlindependent_calloc (size_t, size_t, void **);
901 
902 /*
903  independent_comalloc(size_t n_elements, size_t sizes[], void* chunks[]);
904 
905  independent_comalloc allocates, all at once, a set of n_elements
906  chunks with sizes indicated in the "sizes" array. It returns
907  an array of pointers to these elements, each of which can be
908  independently freed, realloc'ed etc. The elements are guaranteed to
909  be adjacently allocated (this is not guaranteed to occur with
910  multiple callocs or mallocs), which may also improve cache locality
911  in some applications.
912 
913  The "chunks" argument is optional (i.e., may be null). If it is null
914  the returned array is itself dynamically allocated and should also
915  be freed when it is no longer needed. Otherwise, the chunks array
916  must be of at least n_elements in length. It is filled in with the
917  pointers to the chunks.
918 
919  In either case, independent_comalloc returns this pointer array, or
920  null if the allocation failed. If n_elements is zero and chunks is
921  null, it returns a chunk representing an array with zero elements
922  (which should be freed if not wanted).
923 
924  Each element must be individually freed when it is no longer
925  needed. If you'd like to instead be able to free all at once, you
926  should instead use a single regular malloc, and assign pointers at
927  particular offsets in the aggregate space. (In this case though, you
928  cannot independently free elements.)
929 
930  independent_comallac differs from independent_calloc in that each
931  element may have a different size, and also that it does not
932  automatically clear elements.
933 
934  independent_comalloc can be used to speed up allocation in cases
935  where several structs or objects must always be allocated at the
936  same time. For example:
937 
938  struct Head { ... }
939  struct Foot { ... }
940 
941  void send_message(char* msg) {
942  int msglen = strlen(msg);
943  size_t sizes[3] = { sizeof(struct Head), msglen, sizeof(struct Foot) };
944  void* chunks[3];
945  if (independent_comalloc(3, sizes, chunks) == 0)
946  die();
947  struct Head* head = (struct Head*)(chunks[0]);
948  char* body = (char*)(chunks[1]);
949  struct Foot* foot = (struct Foot*)(chunks[2]);
950  // ...
951  }
952 
953  In general though, independent_comalloc is worth using only for
954  larger values of n_elements. For small values, you probably won't
955  detect enough difference from series of malloc calls to bother.
956 
957  Overuse of independent_comalloc can increase overall memory usage,
958  since it cannot reuse existing noncontiguous small chunks that
959  might be available for some of the elements.
960 */
961  void **dlindependent_comalloc (size_t, size_t *, void **);
962 
963 
964 /*
965  pvalloc(size_t n);
966  Equivalent to valloc(minimum-page-that-holds(n)), that is,
967  round up n to nearest pagesize.
968  */
969  void *dlpvalloc (size_t);
970 
971 /*
972  malloc_trim(size_t pad);
973 
974  If possible, gives memory back to the system (via negative arguments
975  to sbrk) if there is unused memory at the `high' end of the malloc
976  pool or in unused MMAP segments. You can call this after freeing
977  large blocks of memory to potentially reduce the system-level memory
978  requirements of a program. However, it cannot guarantee to reduce
979  memory. Under some allocation patterns, some large free blocks of
980  memory will be locked between two used chunks, so they cannot be
981  given back to the system.
982 
983  The `pad' argument to malloc_trim represents the amount of free
984  trailing space to leave untrimmed. If this argument is zero, only
985  the minimum amount of memory to maintain internal data structures
986  will be left. Non-zero arguments can be supplied to maintain enough
987  trailing space to service future expected allocations without having
988  to re-obtain memory from the system.
989 
990  Malloc_trim returns 1 if it actually released any memory, else 0.
991 */
992  int dlmalloc_trim (size_t);
993 
994 /*
995  malloc_usable_size(void* p);
996 
997  Returns the number of bytes you can actually use in
998  an allocated chunk, which may be more than you requested (although
999  often not) due to alignment and minimum size constraints.
1000  You can use this many bytes without worrying about
1001  overwriting other allocated objects. This is not a particularly great
1002  programming practice. malloc_usable_size can be more useful in
1003  debugging and assertions, for example:
1004 
1005  p = malloc(n);
1006  assert(malloc_usable_size(p) >= 256);
1007 */
1008  size_t dlmalloc_usable_size (void *);
1009 
1010 /*
1011  malloc_stats();
1012  Prints on stderr the amount of space obtained from the system (both
1013  via sbrk and mmap), the maximum amount (which may be more than
1014  current if malloc_trim and/or munmap got called), and the current
1015  number of bytes allocated via malloc (or realloc, etc) but not yet
1016  freed. Note that this is the number of bytes allocated, not the
1017  number requested. It will be larger than the number requested
1018  because of alignment and bookkeeping overhead. Because it includes
1019  alignment wastage as being in use, this figure may be greater than
1020  zero even when no user-level chunks are allocated.
1021 
1022  The reported current and maximum system memory can be inaccurate if
1023  a program makes other calls to system memory allocation functions
1024  (normally sbrk) outside of malloc.
1025 
1026  malloc_stats prints only the most commonly interesting statistics.
1027  More information can be obtained by calling mallinfo.
1028 */
1029  void dlmalloc_stats (void);
1030 
1031 #endif /* ONLY_MSPACES */
1032 
1033 #if MSPACES
1034 
1035 /*
1036  mspace is an opaque type representing an independent
1037  region of space that supports mspace_malloc, etc.
1038 */
1039  typedef void *mspace;
1040 
1041 /*
1042  create_mspace creates and returns a new independent space with the
1043  given initial capacity, or, if 0, the default granularity size. It
1044  returns null if there is no system memory available to create the
1045  space. If argument locked is non-zero, the space uses a separate
1046  lock to control access. The capacity of the space will grow
1047  dynamically as needed to service mspace_malloc requests. You can
1048  control the sizes of incremental increases of this space by
1049  compiling with a different DEFAULT_GRANULARITY or dynamically
1050  setting with mallopt(M_GRANULARITY, value).
1051 */
1052  mspace create_mspace (size_t capacity, int locked);
1053 
1054 /*
1055  destroy_mspace destroys the given space, and attempts to return all
1056  of its memory back to the system, returning the total number of
1057  bytes freed. After destruction, the results of access to all memory
1058  used by the space become undefined.
1059 */
1060  size_t destroy_mspace (mspace msp);
1061 
1062 /*
1063  create_mspace_with_base uses the memory supplied as the initial base
1064  of a new mspace. Part (less than 128*sizeof(size_t) bytes) of this
1065  space is used for bookkeeping, so the capacity must be at least this
1066  large. (Otherwise 0 is returned.) When this initial space is
1067  exhausted, additional memory will be obtained from the system.
1068  Destroying this space will deallocate all additionally allocated
1069  space (if possible) but not the initial base.
1070 */
1071  mspace create_mspace_with_base (void *base, size_t capacity, int locked);
1072 
1073 /*
1074  mspace_malloc behaves as malloc, but operates within
1075  the given space.
1076 */
1077  void *mspace_malloc (mspace msp, size_t bytes);
1078 
1079 /*
1080  mspace_free behaves as free, but operates within
1081  the given space.
1082 
1083  If compiled with FOOTERS==1, mspace_free is not actually needed.
1084  free may be called instead of mspace_free because freed chunks from
1085  any space are handled by their originating spaces.
1086 */
1087  void mspace_free (mspace msp, void *mem);
1088 
1089 /*
1090  mspace_realloc behaves as realloc, but operates within
1091  the given space.
1092 
1093  If compiled with FOOTERS==1, mspace_realloc is not actually
1094  needed. realloc may be called instead of mspace_realloc because
1095  realloced chunks from any space are handled by their originating
1096  spaces.
1097 */
1098  void *mspace_realloc (mspace msp, void *mem, size_t newsize);
1099 
1100 /*
1101  mspace_calloc behaves as calloc, but operates within
1102  the given space.
1103 */
1104  void *mspace_calloc (mspace msp, size_t n_elements, size_t elem_size);
1105 
1106 /*
1107  mspace_memalign behaves as memalign, but operates within
1108  the given space.
1109 */
1110  void *mspace_memalign (mspace msp, size_t alignment, size_t bytes);
1111 
1112 /*
1113  mspace_independent_calloc behaves as independent_calloc, but
1114  operates within the given space.
1115 */
1116  void **mspace_independent_calloc (mspace msp, size_t n_elements, size_t elem_size, void *chunks[]);
1117 
1118 /*
1119  mspace_independent_comalloc behaves as independent_comalloc, but
1120  operates within the given space.
1121 */
1122  void **mspace_independent_comalloc (mspace msp, size_t n_elements, size_t sizes[], void *chunks[]);
1123 
1124 /*
1125  mspace_footprint() returns the number of bytes obtained from the
1126  system for this space.
1127 */
1128  size_t mspace_footprint (mspace msp);
1129 
1130 /*
1131  mspace_max_footprint() returns the peak number of bytes obtained from the
1132  system for this space.
1133 */
1134  size_t mspace_max_footprint (mspace msp);
1135 
1136 
1137 #if !NO_MALLINFO
1138 /*
1139  mspace_mallinfo behaves as mallinfo, but reports properties of
1140  the given space.
1141 */
1142  struct mallinfo mspace_mallinfo (mspace msp);
1143 #endif /* NO_MALLINFO */
1144 
1145 /*
1146  mspace_malloc_stats behaves as malloc_stats, but reports
1147  properties of the given space.
1148 */
1149  void mspace_malloc_stats (mspace msp);
1150 
1151 /*
1152  mspace_trim behaves as malloc_trim, but
1153  operates within the given space.
1154 */
1155  int mspace_trim (mspace msp, size_t pad);
1156 
1157 /*
1158  An alias for mallopt.
1159 */
1160  int mspace_mallopt (int, int);
1161 
1162 #endif /* MSPACES */
1163 
1164 #ifdef __cplusplus
1165 }; /* end of extern "C" */
1166 #endif /* __cplusplus */

1172  on the next line, as well as in programs that use this malloc.
1173  ========================================================================

1280 /* ------------------- size_t and alignment properties -------------------- */
1281 
1282 /* The byte and bit size of a size_t */
1283 #define SIZE_T_SIZE (sizeof(size_t))
1284 #define SIZE_T_BITSIZE (sizeof(size_t) << 3)
1285 
1286 /* Some constants coerced to size_t */
1287 /* Annoying but necessary to avoid errors on some plaftorms */
1288 #define SIZE_T_ZERO ((size_t)0)
1289 #define SIZE_T_ONE ((size_t)1)
1290 #define SIZE_T_TWO ((size_t)2)
1291 #define TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES (SIZE_T_SIZE<<1)
1292 #define FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES (SIZE_T_SIZE<<2)
1293 #define SIX_SIZE_T_SIZES (FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES+TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES)
1294 #define HALF_MAX_SIZE_T (MAX_SIZE_T / 2U)
1295 
1296 /* The bit mask value corresponding to MALLOC_ALIGNMENT */
1297 #define CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK (MALLOC_ALIGNMENT - SIZE_T_ONE)
1298 
1299 /* True if address a has acceptable alignment */
1300 #define is_aligned(A) (((size_t)((A)) & (CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)) == 0)
1301 
1302 /* the number of bytes to offset an address to align it */
1303 #define align_offset(A)\
1304  ((((size_t)(A) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) == 0)? 0 :\
1305  ((MALLOC_ALIGNMENT - ((size_t)(A) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)) & CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK))

1349 #else /* MAP_ANONYMOUS */

1351  Nearly all versions of mmap support MAP_ANONYMOUS, so the following
1352  is unlikely to be needed, but is supplied just in case.
1353 */
1354 #define MMAP_FLAGS (MAP_PRIVATE)
1355 static int dev_zero_fd = -1; /* Cached file descriptor for /dev/zero. */
1356 #define CALL_MMAP(s) ((dev_zero_fd < 0) ? \
1357  (dev_zero_fd = open("/dev/zero", O_RDWR), \
1358  mmap(0, (s), MMAP_PROT, MMAP_FLAGS, dev_zero_fd, 0)) : \
1359  mmap(0, (s), MMAP_PROT, MMAP_FLAGS, dev_zero_fd, 0))
1360 #endif /* MAP_ANONYMOUS */
1361

1363 #else /* WIN32 */

1365 /* Win32 MMAP via VirtualAlloc */
1366 static void *
1367 win32mmap (size_t size)
1368 {
1369  void *ptr = VirtualAlloc (0, size, MEM_RESERVE | MEM_COMMIT, PAGE_READWRITE);
1370  return (ptr != 0) ? ptr : MFAIL;
1371 }
1372 
1373 /* For direct MMAP, use MEM_TOP_DOWN to minimize interference */
1374 static void *
1375 win32direct_mmap (size_t size)
1376 {
1377  void *ptr = VirtualAlloc (0, size, MEM_RESERVE | MEM_COMMIT | MEM_TOP_DOWN,
1378  PAGE_READWRITE);
1379  return (ptr != 0) ? ptr : MFAIL;
1380 }
1381 
1382 /* This function supports releasing coalesed segments */
1383 static int
1384 win32munmap (void *ptr, size_t size)
1385 {
1386  MEMORY_BASIC_INFORMATION minfo;
1387  char *cptr = ptr;
1388  while (size)
1389  {
1390  if (VirtualQuery (cptr, &minfo, sizeof (minfo)) == 0)
1391  return -1;
1392  if (minfo.BaseAddress != cptr || minfo.AllocationBase != cptr ||
1393  minfo.State != MEM_COMMIT || minfo.RegionSize > size)
1394  return -1;
1395  if (VirtualFree (cptr, 0, MEM_RELEASE) == 0)
1396  return -1;
1397  cptr += minfo.RegionSize;
1398  size -= minfo.RegionSize;
1399  }
1400  return 0;
1401 }
1402 
1403 #define CALL_MMAP(s) win32mmap(s)
1404 #define CALL_MUNMAP(a, s) win32munmap((a), (s))
1405 #define DIRECT_MMAP(s) win32direct_mmap(s)
1406 #endif /* WIN32 */
1407 #endif /* USE_MALLOC_INSTEAD */
1408 #endif /* HAVE_MMAP */

1429 /* --------------------------- Lock preliminaries ------------------------ */
1430 
1431 #if USE_LOCKS
1432 
1433 /*
1434  When locks are defined, there are up to two global locks:
1435 
1436  * If HAVE_MORECORE, morecore_mutex protects sequences of calls to
1437  MORECORE. In many cases sys_alloc requires two calls, that should
1438  not be interleaved with calls by other threads. This does not
1439  protect against direct calls to MORECORE by other threads not
1440  using this lock, so there is still code to cope the best we can on
1441  interference.
1442 
1443  * magic_init_mutex ensures that mparams.magic and other
1444  unique mparams values are initialized only once.
1445 */
1446 
1447 #ifndef WIN32
1448 /* By default use posix locks */
1449 #include <pthread.h>
1450 #define MLOCK_T pthread_mutex_t
1451 #define INITIAL_LOCK(l) pthread_mutex_init(l, NULL)
1452 #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(l) pthread_mutex_lock(l)
1453 #define RELEASE_LOCK(l) pthread_mutex_unlock(l)
1454 
1455 #if HAVE_MORECORE
1456 static MLOCK_T morecore_mutex = PTHREAD_MUTEX_INITIALIZER;
1457 #endif /* HAVE_MORECORE */
1458 
1459 static MLOCK_T magic_init_mutex = PTHREAD_MUTEX_INITIALIZER;
1460 
1461 #else /* WIN32 */
1462 /*
1463  Because lock-protected regions have bounded times, and there
1464  are no recursive lock calls, we can use simple spinlocks.
1465 */
1466 
1467 #define MLOCK_T long
1468 static int
1469 win32_acquire_lock (MLOCK_T * sl)
1470 {
1471  for (;;)
1472  {
1473 #ifdef InterlockedCompareExchangePointer
1474  if (!InterlockedCompareExchange (sl, 1, 0))
1475  return 0;
1476 #else /* Use older void* version */
1477  if (!InterlockedCompareExchange ((void **) sl, (void *) 1, (void *) 0))
1478  return 0;
1479 #endif /* InterlockedCompareExchangePointer */
1480  Sleep (0);
1481  }
1482 }
1483 
1484 static void
1485 win32_release_lock (MLOCK_T * sl)
1486 {
1487  InterlockedExchange (sl, 0);
1488 }
1489 
1490 #define INITIAL_LOCK(l) *(l)=0
1491 #define ACQUIRE_LOCK(l) win32_acquire_lock(l)
1492 #define RELEASE_LOCK(l) win32_release_lock(l)
1493 #if HAVE_MORECORE
1494 static MLOCK_T morecore_mutex;
1495 #endif /* HAVE_MORECORE */
1496 static MLOCK_T magic_init_mutex;
1497 #endif /* WIN32 */
1498 
1499 #define USE_LOCK_BIT (2U)
1500 #else /* USE_LOCKS */
1501 #define USE_LOCK_BIT (0U)
1502 #define INITIAL_LOCK(l)
1503 #endif /* USE_LOCKS */
1504 
1505 #if USE_LOCKS && HAVE_MORECORE
1506 #define ACQUIRE_MORECORE_LOCK() ACQUIRE_LOCK(&morecore_mutex);
1507 #define RELEASE_MORECORE_LOCK() RELEASE_LOCK(&morecore_mutex);
1508 #else /* USE_LOCKS && HAVE_MORECORE */
1509 #define ACQUIRE_MORECORE_LOCK()
1510 #define RELEASE_MORECORE_LOCK()
1511 #endif /* USE_LOCKS && HAVE_MORECORE */
1512 
1513 #if USE_LOCKS
1514 #define ACQUIRE_MAGIC_INIT_LOCK() ACQUIRE_LOCK(&magic_init_mutex);
1515 #define RELEASE_MAGIC_INIT_LOCK() RELEASE_LOCK(&magic_init_mutex);
1516 #else /* USE_LOCKS */
1517 #define ACQUIRE_MAGIC_INIT_LOCK()
1518 #define RELEASE_MAGIC_INIT_LOCK()
1519 #endif /* USE_LOCKS */
