1521 
1522 /* ----------------------- Chunk representations ------------------------ */
1523 
1524 /*
1525  (The following includes lightly edited explanations by Colin Plumb.)
1526 
1527  The malloc_chunk declaration below is misleading (but accurate and
1528  necessary). It declares a "view" into memory allowing access to
1529  necessary fields at known offsets from a given base.
1530 
1531  Chunks of memory are maintained using a `boundary tag' method as
1532  originally described by Knuth. (See the paper by Paul Wilson
1533  ftp://ftp.cs.utexas.edu/pub/garbage/allocsrv.ps for a survey of such
1534  techniques.) Sizes of free chunks are stored both in the front of
1535  each chunk and at the end. This makes consolidating fragmented
1536  chunks into bigger chunks fast. The head fields also hold bits
1537  representing whether chunks are free or in use.
1538 
1539  Here are some pictures to make it clearer. They are "exploded" to
1540  show that the state of a chunk can be thought of as extending from
1541  the high 31 bits of the head field of its header through the
1542  prev_foot and PINUSE_BIT bit of the following chunk header.
1543 
1544  A chunk that's in use looks like:
1545 
1546  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1547  | Size of previous chunk (if P = 1) |
1548  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1549  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |P|
1550  | Size of this chunk 1| +-+
1551  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1552  | |
1553  +- -+
1554  | |
1555  +- -+
1556  | :
1557  +- size - sizeof(size_t) available payload bytes -+
1558  : |
1559  chunk-> +- -+
1560  | |
1561  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1562  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |1|
1563  | Size of next chunk (may or may not be in use) | +-+
1564  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1565 
1566  And if it's free, it looks like this:
1567 
1568  chunk-> +- -+
1569  | User payload (must be in use, or we would have merged!) |
1570  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1571  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |P|
1572  | Size of this chunk 0| +-+
1573  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1574  | Next pointer |
1575  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1576  | Prev pointer |
1577  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1578  | :
1579  +- size - sizeof(struct chunk) unused bytes -+
1580  : |
1581  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1582  | Size of this chunk |
1583  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1584  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+ |0|
1585  | Size of next chunk (must be in use, or we would have merged)| +-+
1586  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1587  | :
1588  +- User payload -+
1589  : |
1590  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1591  |0|
1592  +-+
1593  Note that since we always merge adjacent free chunks, the chunks
1594  adjacent to a free chunk must be in use.
1595 
1596  Given a pointer to a chunk (which can be derived trivially from the
1597  payload pointer) we can, in O(1) time, find out whether the adjacent
1598  chunks are free, and if so, unlink them from the lists that they
1599  are on and merge them with the current chunk.
1600 
1601  Chunks always begin on even word boundaries, so the mem portion
1602  (which is returned to the user) is also on an even word boundary, and
1603  thus at least double-word aligned.
1604 
1605  The P (PINUSE_BIT) bit, stored in the unused low-order bit of the
1606  chunk size (which is always a multiple of two words), is an in-use
1607  bit for the *previous* chunk. If that bit is *clear*, then the
1608  word before the current chunk size contains the previous chunk
1609  size, and can be used to find the front of the previous chunk.
1610  The very first chunk allocated always has this bit set, preventing
1611  access to non-existent (or non-owned) memory. If pinuse is set for
1612  any given chunk, then you CANNOT determine the size of the
1613  previous chunk, and might even get a memory addressing fault when
1614  trying to do so.
1615 
1616  The C (CINUSE_BIT) bit, stored in the unused second-lowest bit of
1617  the chunk size redundantly records whether the current chunk is
1618  inuse. This redundancy enables usage checks within free and realloc,
1619  and reduces indirection when freeing and consolidating chunks.
1620 
1621  Each freshly allocated chunk must have both cinuse and pinuse set.
1622  That is, each allocated chunk borders either a previously allocated
1623  and still in-use chunk, or the base of its memory arena. This is
1624  ensured by making all allocations from the the `lowest' part of any
1625  found chunk. Further, no free chunk physically borders another one,
1626  so each free chunk is known to be preceded and followed by either
1627  inuse chunks or the ends of memory.
1628 
1629  Note that the `foot' of the current chunk is actually represented
1630  as the prev_foot of the NEXT chunk. This makes it easier to
1631  deal with alignments etc but can be very confusing when trying
1632  to extend or adapt this code.
1633 
1634  The exceptions to all this are
1635 
1636  1. The special chunk `top' is the top-most available chunk (i.e.,
1637  the one bordering the end of available memory). It is treated
1638  specially. Top is never included in any bin, is used only if
1639  no other chunk is available, and is released back to the
1640  system if it is very large (see M_TRIM_THRESHOLD). In effect,
1641  the top chunk is treated as larger (and thus less well
1642  fitting) than any other available chunk. The top chunk
1643  doesn't update its trailing size field since there is no next
1644  contiguous chunk that would have to index off it. However,
1645  space is still allocated for it (TOP_FOOT_SIZE) to enable
1646  separation or merging when space is extended.
1647 
1648  3. Chunks allocated via mmap, which have the lowest-order bit
1649  (IS_MMAPPED_BIT) set in their prev_foot fields, and do not set
1650  PINUSE_BIT in their head fields. Because they are allocated
1651  one-by-one, each must carry its own prev_foot field, which is
1652  also used to hold the offset this chunk has within its mmapped
1653  region, which is needed to preserve alignment. Each mmapped
1654  chunk is trailed by the first two fields of a fake next-chunk
1655  for sake of usage checks.
1656 
1657 */
1658 
1659 struct malloc_chunk
1660 {
1661  size_t prev_foot; /* Size of previous chunk (if free). */
1662  size_t head; /* Size and inuse bits. */
1663  struct malloc_chunk *fd; /* double links -- used only if free. */
1664  struct malloc_chunk *bk;
1665 };
1666 
1667 typedef struct malloc_chunk mchunk;
1668 typedef struct malloc_chunk *mchunkptr;
1669 typedef struct malloc_chunk *sbinptr; /* The type of bins of chunks */
1670 typedef unsigned int bindex_t; /* Described below */
1671 typedef unsigned int binmap_t; /* Described below */
1672 typedef unsigned int flag_t; /* The type of various bit flag sets */
1673 
1674 /* ------------------- Chunks sizes and alignments ----------------------- */
1675 
1676 #define MCHUNK_SIZE (sizeof(mchunk))
1677 
1678 #if FOOTERS
1679 #define CHUNK_OVERHEAD (TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES)
1680 #else /* FOOTERS */
1681 #define CHUNK_OVERHEAD (SIZE_T_SIZE)
1682 #endif /* FOOTERS */
1683 
1684 /* MMapped chunks need a second word of overhead ... */
1685 #define MMAP_CHUNK_OVERHEAD (TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES)
1686 /* ... and additional padding for fake next-chunk at foot */
1687 #define MMAP_FOOT_PAD (FOUR_SIZE_T_SIZES)
1688 
1689 /* The smallest size we can malloc is an aligned minimal chunk */
1690 #define MIN_CHUNK_SIZE\
1691  ((MCHUNK_SIZE + CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) & ~CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)
1692 
1693 /* conversion from malloc headers to user pointers, and back */
1694 #define chunk2mem(p) ((void*)((char*)(p) + TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES))
1695 #define mem2chunk(mem) ((mchunkptr)((char*)(mem) - TWO_SIZE_T_SIZES))
1696 /* chunk associated with aligned address A */
1697 #define align_as_chunk(A) (mchunkptr)((A) + align_offset(chunk2mem(A)))
1698 
1699 /* Bounds on request (not chunk) sizes. */
1700 #define MAX_REQUEST ((-MIN_CHUNK_SIZE) << 2)
1701 #define MIN_REQUEST (MIN_CHUNK_SIZE - CHUNK_OVERHEAD - SIZE_T_ONE)
1702 
1703 /* pad request bytes into a usable size */
1704 #define pad_request(req) \
1705  (((req) + CHUNK_OVERHEAD + CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK) & ~CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK)
1706 
1707 /* pad request, checking for minimum (but not maximum) */
1708 #define request2size(req) \
1709  (((req) < MIN_REQUEST)? MIN_CHUNK_SIZE : pad_request(req))
1710 
1711 
1712 /* ------------------ Operations on head and foot fields ----------------- */
1713 
1714 /*
1715  The head field of a chunk is or'ed with PINUSE_BIT when previous
1716  adjacent chunk in use, and or'ed with CINUSE_BIT if this chunk is in
1717  use. If the chunk was obtained with mmap, the prev_foot field has
1718  IS_MMAPPED_BIT set, otherwise holding the offset of the base of the
1719  mmapped region to the base of the chunk.
1720 */
1721 
1722 #define PINUSE_BIT (SIZE_T_ONE)
1723 #define CINUSE_BIT (SIZE_T_TWO)
1724 #define INUSE_BITS (PINUSE_BIT|CINUSE_BIT)
1725 
1726 /* Head value for fenceposts */
1727 #define FENCEPOST_HEAD (INUSE_BITS|SIZE_T_SIZE)
1728 
1729 /* extraction of fields from head words */
1730 #define cinuse(p) ((p)->head & CINUSE_BIT)
1731 #define pinuse(p) ((p)->head & PINUSE_BIT)
1732 #define chunksize(p) ((p)->head & ~(INUSE_BITS))
1733 
1734 #define clear_pinuse(p) ((p)->head &= ~PINUSE_BIT)
1735 #define clear_cinuse(p) ((p)->head &= ~CINUSE_BIT)
1736 
1737 /* Treat space at ptr +/- offset as a chunk */
1738 #define chunk_plus_offset(p, s) ((mchunkptr)(((char*)(p)) + (s)))
1739 #define chunk_minus_offset(p, s) ((mchunkptr)(((char*)(p)) - (s)))
1740 
1741 /* Ptr to next or previous physical malloc_chunk. */
1742 #define next_chunk(p) ((mchunkptr)( ((char*)(p)) + ((p)->head & ~INUSE_BITS)))
1743 #define prev_chunk(p) ((mchunkptr)( ((char*)(p)) - ((p)->prev_foot) ))
1744 
1745 /* extract next chunk's pinuse bit */
1746 #define next_pinuse(p) ((next_chunk(p)->head) & PINUSE_BIT)
1747 
1748 /* Get/set size at footer */
1749 #define get_foot(p, s) (((mchunkptr)((char*)(p) + (s)))->prev_foot)
1750 #define set_foot(p, s) (((mchunkptr)((char*)(p) + (s)))->prev_foot = (s))
1751 
1752 /* Set size, pinuse bit, and foot */
1753 #define set_size_and_pinuse_of_free_chunk(p, s)\
1754  ((p)->head = (s|PINUSE_BIT), set_foot(p, s))
1755 
1756 /* Set size, pinuse bit, foot, and clear next pinuse */
1757 #define set_free_with_pinuse(p, s, n)\
1758  (clear_pinuse(n), set_size_and_pinuse_of_free_chunk(p, s))
1759 
1760 #define is_mmapped(p)\
1761  (!((p)->head & PINUSE_BIT) && ((p)->prev_foot & IS_MMAPPED_BIT))
1762 
1763 /* Get the internal overhead associated with chunk p */
1764 #define overhead_for(p)\
1765  (is_mmapped(p)? MMAP_CHUNK_OVERHEAD : CHUNK_OVERHEAD)
1766 
1767 /* Return true if malloced space is not necessarily cleared */
1768 #if MMAP_CLEARS
1769 #define calloc_must_clear(p) (!is_mmapped(p))
1770 #else /* MMAP_CLEARS */
1771 #define calloc_must_clear(p) (1)
1772 #endif /* MMAP_CLEARS */
1773 
1774 /* ---------------------- Overlaid data structures ----------------------- */
1775 
1776 /*
1777  When chunks are not in use, they are treated as nodes of either
1778  lists or trees.
1779 
1780  "Small" chunks are stored in circular doubly-linked lists, and look
1781  like this:
1782 
1783  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1784  | Size of previous chunk |
1785  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1786  `head:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |P|
1787  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1788  | Forward pointer to next chunk in list |
1789  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1790  | Back pointer to previous chunk in list |
1791  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1792  | Unused space (may be 0 bytes long) .
1793  . .
1794  . |
1795 nextchunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1796  `foot:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |
1797  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1798 
1799  Larger chunks are kept in a form of bitwise digital trees (aka
1800  tries) keyed on chunksizes. Because malloc_tree_chunks are only for
1801  free chunks greater than 256 bytes, their size doesn't impose any
1802  constraints on user chunk sizes. Each node looks like:
1803 
1804  chunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1805  | Size of previous chunk |
1806  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1807  `head:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |P|
1808  mem-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1809  | Forward pointer to next chunk of same size |
1810  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1811  | Back pointer to previous chunk of same size |
1812  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1813  | Pointer to left child (child[0]) |
1814  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1815  | Pointer to right child (child[1]) |
1816  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1817  | Pointer to parent |
1818  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1819  | bin index of this chunk |
1820  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1821  | Unused space .
1822  . |
1823 nextchunk-> +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1824  `foot:' | Size of chunk, in bytes |
1825  +-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+-+
1826 
1827  Each tree holding treenodes is a tree of unique chunk sizes. Chunks
1828  of the same size are arranged in a circularly-linked list, with only
1829  the oldest chunk (the next to be used, in our FIFO ordering)
1830  actually in the tree. (Tree members are distinguished by a non-null
1831  parent pointer.) If a chunk with the same size an an existing node
1832  is inserted, it is linked off the existing node using pointers that
1833  work in the same way as fd/bk pointers of small chunks.
1834 
1835  Each tree contains a power of 2 sized range of chunk sizes (the
1836  smallest is 0x100 <= x < 0x180), which is is divided in half at each
1837  tree level, with the chunks in the smaller half of the range (0x100
1838  <= x < 0x140 for the top nose) in the left subtree and the larger
1839  half (0x140 <= x < 0x180) in the right subtree. This is, of course,
1840  done by inspecting individual bits.
1841 
1842  Using these rules, each node's left subtree contains all smaller
1843  sizes than its right subtree. However, the node at the root of each
1844  subtree has no particular ordering relationship to either. (The
1845  dividing line between the subtree sizes is based on trie relation.)
1846  If we remove the last chunk of a given size from the interior of the
1847  tree, we need to replace it with a leaf node. The tree ordering
1848  rules permit a node to be replaced by any leaf below it.
1849 
1850  The smallest chunk in a tree (a common operation in a best-fit
1851  allocator) can be found by walking a path to the leftmost leaf in
1852  the tree. Unlike a usual binary tree, where we follow left child
1853  pointers until we reach a null, here we follow the right child
1854  pointer any time the left one is null, until we reach a leaf with
1855  both child pointers null. The smallest chunk in the tree will be
1856  somewhere along that path.
1857 
1858  The worst case number of steps to add, find, or remove a node is
1859  bounded by the number of bits differentiating chunks within
1860  bins. Under current bin calculations, this ranges from 6 up to 21
1861  (for 32 bit sizes) or up to 53 (for 64 bit sizes). The typical case
1862  is of course much better.
1863 */
1864 
1865 struct malloc_tree_chunk
1866 {
1867  /* The first four fields must be compatible with malloc_chunk */
1868  size_t prev_foot;
1869  size_t head;
1870  struct malloc_tree_chunk *fd;
1871  struct malloc_tree_chunk *bk;
1872 
1873  struct malloc_tree_chunk *child[2];
1874  struct malloc_tree_chunk *parent;
1875  bindex_t index;
1876 };
1877 
1878 typedef struct malloc_tree_chunk tchunk;
1879 typedef struct malloc_tree_chunk *tchunkptr;
1880 typedef struct malloc_tree_chunk *tbinptr; /* The type of bins of trees */
1881 
1882 /* A little helper macro for trees */
1883 #define leftmost_child(t) ((t)->child[0] != 0? (t)->child[0] : (t)->child[1])
1884 
1885 /* ----------------------------- Segments -------------------------------- */
1886 
1887 /*
1888  Each malloc space may include non-contiguous segments, held in a
1889  list headed by an embedded malloc_segment record representing the
1890  top-most space. Segments also include flags holding properties of
1891  the space. Large chunks that are directly allocated by mmap are not
1892  included in this list. They are instead independently created and
1893  destroyed without otherwise keeping track of them.
1894 
1895  Segment management mainly comes into play for spaces allocated by
1896  MMAP. Any call to MMAP might or might not return memory that is
1897  adjacent to an existing segment. MORECORE normally contiguously
1898  extends the current space, so this space is almost always adjacent,
1899  which is simpler and faster to deal with. (This is why MORECORE is
1900  used preferentially to MMAP when both are available -- see
1901  sys_alloc.) When allocating using MMAP, we don't use any of the
1902  hinting mechanisms (inconsistently) supported in various
1903  implementations of unix mmap, or distinguish reserving from
1904  committing memory. Instead, we just ask for space, and exploit
1905  contiguity when we get it. It is probably possible to do
1906  better than this on some systems, but no general scheme seems
1907  to be significantly better.
1908 
1909  Management entails a simpler variant of the consolidation scheme
1910  used for chunks to reduce fragmentation -- new adjacent memory is
1911  normally prepended or appended to an existing segment. However,
1912  there are limitations compared to chunk consolidation that mostly
1913  reflect the fact that segment processing is relatively infrequent
1914  (occurring only when getting memory from system) and that we
1915  don't expect to have huge numbers of segments:
1916 
1917  * Segments are not indexed, so traversal requires linear scans. (It
1918  would be possible to index these, but is not worth the extra
1919  overhead and complexity for most programs on most platforms.)
1920  * New segments are only appended to old ones when holding top-most
1921  memory; if they cannot be prepended to others, they are held in
1922  different segments.
1923 
1924  Except for the top-most segment of an mstate, each segment record
1925  is kept at the tail of its segment. Segments are added by pushing
1926  segment records onto the list headed by &mstate.seg for the
1927  containing mstate.
1928 
1929  Segment flags control allocation/merge/deallocation policies:
1930  * If EXTERN_BIT set, then we did not allocate this segment,
1931  and so should not try to deallocate or merge with others.
1932  (This currently holds only for the initial segment passed
1933  into create_mspace_with_base.)
1934  * If IS_MMAPPED_BIT set, the segment may be merged with
1935  other surrounding mmapped segments and trimmed/de-allocated
1936  using munmap.
1937  * If neither bit is set, then the segment was obtained using
1938  MORECORE so can be merged with surrounding MORECORE'd segments
1939  and deallocated/trimmed using MORECORE with negative arguments.
1940 */
1941 
1942 struct malloc_segment
1943 {
1944  char *base; /* base address */
1945  size_t size; /* allocated size */
1946  struct malloc_segment *next; /* ptr to next segment */
1947  flag_t sflags; /* mmap and extern flag */
1948 };
1949 
1950 #define is_mmapped_segment(S) ((S)->sflags & IS_MMAPPED_BIT)
1951 #define is_extern_segment(S) ((S)->sflags & EXTERN_BIT)
1952 
1953 typedef struct malloc_segment msegment;
1954 typedef struct malloc_segment *msegmentptr;
1955 
1956 /* ---------------------------- malloc_state ----------------------------- */
1957 
1958 /*
1959  A malloc_state holds all of the bookkeeping for a space.
1960  The main fields are:
1961 
1962  Top
1963  The topmost chunk of the currently active segment. Its size is
1964  cached in topsize. The actual size of topmost space is
1965  topsize+TOP_FOOT_SIZE, which includes space reserved for adding
1966  fenceposts and segment records if necessary when getting more
1967  space from the system. The size at which to autotrim top is
1968  cached from mparams in trim_check, except that it is disabled if
1969  an autotrim fails.
1970 
1971  Designated victim (dv)
1972  This is the preferred chunk for servicing small requests that
1973  don't have exact fits. It is normally the chunk split off most
1974  recently to service another small request. Its size is cached in
1975  dvsize. The link fields of this chunk are not maintained since it
1976  is not kept in a bin.
1977 
1978  SmallBins
1979  An array of bin headers for free chunks. These bins hold chunks
1980  with sizes less than MIN_LARGE_SIZE bytes. Each bin contains
1981  chunks of all the same size, spaced 8 bytes apart. To simplify
1982  use in double-linked lists, each bin header acts as a malloc_chunk
1983  pointing to the real first node, if it exists (else pointing to
1984  itself). This avoids special-casing for headers. But to avoid
1985  waste, we allocate only the fd/bk pointers of bins, and then use
1986  repositioning tricks to treat these as the fields of a chunk.
1987 
1988  TreeBins
1989  Treebins are pointers to the roots of trees holding a range of
1990  sizes. There are 2 equally spaced treebins for each power of two
1991  from TREE_SHIFT to TREE_SHIFT+16. The last bin holds anything
1992  larger.
1993 
1994  Bin maps
1995  There is one bit map for small bins ("smallmap") and one for
1996  treebins ("treemap). Each bin sets its bit when non-empty, and
1997  clears the bit when empty. Bit operations are then used to avoid
1998  bin-by-bin searching -- nearly all "search" is done without ever
1999  looking at bins that won't be selected. The bit maps
2000  conservatively use 32 bits per map word, even if on 64bit system.
2001  For a good description of some of the bit-based techniques used
2002  here, see Henry S. Warren Jr's book "Hacker's Delight" (and
2003  supplement at http://hackersdelight.org/). Many of these are
2004  intended to reduce the branchiness of paths through malloc etc, as
2005  well as to reduce the number of memory locations read or written.
2006 
2007  Segments
2008  A list of segments headed by an embedded malloc_segment record
2009  representing the initial space.
2010 
2011  Address check support
2012  The least_addr field is the least address ever obtained from
2013  MORECORE or MMAP. Attempted frees and reallocs of any address less
2014  than this are trapped (unless INSECURE is defined).
2015 
2016  Magic tag
2017  A cross-check field that should always hold same value as mparams.magic.
2018 
2019  Flags
2020  Bits recording whether to use MMAP, locks, or contiguous MORECORE
2021 
2022  Statistics
2023  Each space keeps track of current and maximum system memory
2024  obtained via MORECORE or MMAP.
2025 
2026  Locking
2027  If USE_LOCKS is defined, the "mutex" lock is acquired and released
2028  around every public call using this mspace.
2029 */
2030 
2031 /* Bin types, widths and sizes */
2032 #define NSMALLBINS (32U)
2033 #define NTREEBINS (32U)
2034 #define SMALLBIN_SHIFT (3U)
2035 #define SMALLBIN_WIDTH (SIZE_T_ONE << SMALLBIN_SHIFT)
2036 #define TREEBIN_SHIFT (8U)
2037 #define MIN_LARGE_SIZE (SIZE_T_ONE << TREEBIN_SHIFT)
2038 #define MAX_SMALL_SIZE (MIN_LARGE_SIZE - SIZE_T_ONE)
2039 #define MAX_SMALL_REQUEST (MAX_SMALL_SIZE - CHUNK_ALIGN_MASK - CHUNK_OVERHEAD)
2040 
2041 struct malloc_state
2042 {
2043  binmap_t smallmap;
2044  binmap_t treemap;
2045  size_t dvsize;
2046  size_t topsize;
2047  char *least_addr;
2048  mchunkptr dv;
2049  mchunkptr top;
2050  size_t trim_check;
2051  size_t magic;
2052  mchunkptr smallbins[(NSMALLBINS + 1) * 2];
2053  tbinptr treebins[NTREEBINS];
2054  size_t footprint;
2055  size_t max_footprint;
2056  flag_t mflags;
2057 #if USE_LOCKS
2058  MLOCK_T mutex; /* locate lock among fields that rarely change */
2059 #endif /* USE_LOCKS */
2060  msegment seg;
2061 };
2062

2126  ((char*)(A) >= S->base && (char*)(A) < S->base + S->size)

2128 /* Return segment holding given address */
2129 static msegmentptr
2130 segment_holding (mstate m, char *addr)
2131 {
2132  msegmentptr sp = &m->seg;
2133  for (;;)
2134  {
2135  if (addr >= sp->base && addr < sp->base + sp->size)
2136  return sp;
2137  if ((sp = sp->next) == 0)
2138  return 0;
2139  }
2140 }
2141 
2142 /* Return true if segment contains a segment link */
2143 static int
2144 has_segment_link (mstate m, msegmentptr ss)
2145 {
2146  msegmentptr sp = &m->seg;
2147  for (;;)
2148  {
2149  if ((char *) sp >= ss->base && (char *) sp < ss->base + ss->size)
2150  return 1;
2151  if ((sp = sp->next) == 0)
2152  return 0;
2153  }
2154 }
